metadata.case_name: First Defendant & Anr. v. Plaintiff (Adopted son of Gurupadappa)

facts.text: One N. J. Gamodia of Bombay took on lease a piece of agricultural land measuring about 4-1/2 acres belonging to one Gurupadappa of Devangere City for the purpose of erecting a Ginning and Pressing Cotton Factory.

Registered lease deed dated October 26, 1914, provided for initial period of 20 years from October 1, 1914 to September 30, 1934, at annual rent of Rs. 350/- in advance; if lessee removes factory before end, still pay rent till end; after 20 years, lessee at liberty to continue as long as desired, paying Rs. 400/- for next 10 years then Rs. 500/- per annum; lessee free to terminate after Oct 1, 1934; lessor binds not to call for possession as long as lessee observes terms.

Lessee at liberty to erect buildings, factories, etc., make alterations; lessor no objection; lessor pays land assessment, lessee pays conversion taxes; lessee entitled to sublet; lease binding on heirs, executors, successors, assigns.
N. J. Gamodia died in 1916 leaving a will appointing executors.
Executors assigned the lease to the second defendant, Gamodia Factories Limited by a deed dated November 27, 1933.
Second defendant continued to pay stipulated rent to lessor Gurupadappa till his death in May 1939.
Second defendant assigned its leasehold interest to the first defendant by a deed dated May 30, 1944.
Leasehold property contains factory, buildings and residential quarters.
After lessor's death, his two widows continued to receive rent from lessees.
Plaintiff is the adopted son of the original lessor and was a minor till some time in 1949.
Plaintiff issued notices to defendants to terminate tenancy on grounds: 1) lease created tenancy at will; 2) original lessee assigned in contravention of lease terms.
Defendants did not vacate; plaintiff instituted suit for declaration that defendants tenants at will, possession wrongful after notice, for ejectment.

Trial court decreed suit: lease for 20 years certain, then tenancy at will terminable by notice; defendants to quit land, road, restore possession after removing machinery but leaving residential quarters.
Lower appellate court affirmed, dismissed appeal, gave 6 months time to vacate.

High Court in Second Appeal No. 61 of 1954 dismissed appeal dated December 23, 1960: after 20 years, tenancy for indefinite period valid for lifetime of lessee and transferees; but second defendant no longer in possession, assignment to first defendant not binding on plaintiff; confirmed decree, 4 months time to vacate.
High Court refused certificate for appeal on March 29, 1961.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on April 20, 1961.

legal_issues.text: Whether the lease dated October 26, 1914 created a permanent tenancy or a tenancy at will or for lifetime after the initial 20 years.
Whether the assignments of the lease to second defendant and then to first defendant were valid and binding on the plaintiff.

petitioner_arguments.text: Lease created permanent tenancy on proper construction; it is a building lease without fixed period after 20 years, presumption of permanency; lessee right to surrender does not make it tenancy at will as no corresponding right to lessor.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Navalram v. Javerilal; Promada Nath Roy v. Srigobind Chowdhry; Forbes v. Hanuman Bhagat; CIT v. Maharajadhiraj Kumar Visheshwar Singh; Janaki Nath Roy v. Dina Nath Kundu

petitioner_arguments.text: Alternatively, if not permanent, then tenancy for lifetime of assignee (second defendant), and first defendant acquired same interest.

respondent_arguments.text: After 20 years, tenancy at will; lessee right to give up possession imports corresponding right to lessor; assignments contravened lease.

court_reasoning.text: Lease for 20 years certain, then lessee liberty to continue as long as desired, paying enhanced rent; lessor bound not to call for possession; heritable, assignable; building lease presumption of permanency not rebutted by lessee's surrender right.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plain construction shows purpose was building lease; no corresponding right to lessor to terminate; permanent tenancy intended.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished cases like Babasaheb v. West Patent Co.; presumption for building leases; stipulation for lessee surrender benefits lessee, does not derogate permanency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parties intended permanent lease given substantial structures, heritable/assignable terms, no lessor termination right.

holdings.text: Lease deed evidences intention to create permanent lease.

precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption of permanent tenancy for building lease where lessor cannot call for possession while rent paid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promada Nath Roy v. Srigobind Chowdhry
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption of permanent lease for building purposes even without fixed period.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Maharajadhiraj Kumar Visheshwar Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: No fixed term, heritable provisions support permanent tenancy for building.

precedents_cited.case_name: Janaki Nath Roy v. Dina Nath Kundu
precedents_cited.relevance: Heritable, assignable building lease without lessor termination right indicates permanency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baboo Lekhraj Roy v. Kunhya Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Indefinite grant enures for lifetime unless hereditary intent; rule inapplicable if fixed term.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babasaheb v. West Patent Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held indefinite lease for lifetime, but terms weaker than present case lacking full heritable clause.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Rent Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned by appellant counsel but not raised in pleadings or High Court, not permitted in SC.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; held lease creates permanent tenancy; plaintiff's suit for ejectment dismissed; no need to consider other contentions like validity of assignments.
outcome.relief_granted: Defendants' possession upheld as permanent tenants

key_quotes.text: "the lessor bound himself not to call upon the lessee at any time to give up possession of the lease-hold as long as the lessee was prepared to observe the terms of the lease"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key stipulation showing no termination right for lessor, supporting permanency.

key_quotes.text: "This lease is binding on me, my heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns as well as on your heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clause 14 emphasizing heritable and assignable nature.

key_quotes.text: "on a true and proper construction of the lease deed, the presumption in favour of the transaction creating a permanent lease cannot be held to have been rebutted"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on construction and presumption.
